Service Bus

Keep applications and equipment connected across private cloud and public cloud scenarios.

Apply for a trial Purchase now

Azure Service Bus is a message transfer infrastructure located among various applications, permitting applications to exchange messages, so as to expand the scale and improve recovery capabilities.

FAQs

Expand all
  • How is the number of relay messages calculated?

    Every message sent to/from the Service Bus Relay is a chargeable message. One message is defined as a data unit equal to or less than 64 KB.

  • How is the number of operating queues and topics calculated?

    For the transfer entity (queue, topic/subscription, message buffer zone), one operation refers to any API call to Service Bus services.

    Sending, receiving or deleting messages less than or equal to 64 KB is considered a chargeable operation. If the message size exceeds 64 KB, the chargeable operand can be calculated as a multiple of 64KB. For instance, a one 8 KB message sent to the Service Bus is charged as one operation, and one 96 KB message sent to the Service Bus is charged as two operations. Reading an 8 KB message by locking, then deleting the message will be charged as two operations.

    The same message sent several times (e.g.: message is sent to several listeners, or withdrawn after cancellation, delay or mailing failure) will be taken as individual operations. For instance, if a topic has 3 subscriptions, a 64KB message sent and then received will be charged as 4 chargeable operations (1 “incoming” and 3 “outgoing” operations, assuming all messages are sent to all subscriptions and deleted after reading).

    You can receive messages by using PeekLock’s ReceiveMode, then deleting the message through a complete call, which will generate two individual operations. Relocking the message will also generate one operation.

    In addition, creating, reading (listing), updating and deleting queues, topics or subscriptions will also generate operation expenses.

    Operation means API calls to the terminals of queues or topics/subscription services, including management, sending/receiving and session state operations.

    Operation Types Description
    Management Create, read, update and delete queues or topics/subscriptions
    Message transfer Sending and receiving message by queues or topics/subscriptions
    Session status Get the status of the queue or topic/subscription session or set the status
  • How are relay hours calculated?

    The relay hours are charged by the cumulative time when every Service Bus Relay is in an “open” status. When the relay-enabled WCF service (i.e. “Relay Listener”) is connected to a given Service Bus address (service namespace URL) for the first time, the interrupt is implicitly instantiated and is opened at this address. The relay will be closed only when the last listener is disconnected from the address. Thus, for the purpose of billing, the relay will be regarded as being in “open” status from the time when the first relay listener is connected to the relay’s Service Bus Address to the time when the last relay listener is disconnected from the address.

  • What is transfer connection and what is its billing method?

    Transfer connection is defined as one of the following connections:

    1. An AMQP connection from the client to Service Bus topics/subscriptions, queues or Event Hubs.
    2. An HTTP call to receiving messages from Service Bus topics or queues with a receiving timeout bigger than zero.
      The charging of concurrent transfer connections exceeding the peak of the attached number (standard level is 1,000). Peak value will be measured once every hour. Expenses are allocated in proportion to 744 hours every month, and accumulated within the billing cycle of every month. At the end of the billing period, the amount added will be applied to the sum of the hourly peaks that are prorated (1,000 transfer connections every month).
      Instances
      1. You can establish connections with 10,000 devices through one AMQP Connection, receive commands from Service Bus topics and send remote-sensing events to Event Hubs. If all equipment is connected 12 hours per day, you’re required to pay the following connection fees (excluding any other Service Bus fees): 10,000 connections * 12 hours * 31 days/744 = 5,000 transfer connections. After deducting the limit of 1,000 connections per month, you need to pay the fee of 4,000 transfer connections at a rate of RMB 0.18 for every transfer connection, totaling RMB 720.
      2. Timeout is not zero when 10,000 devices receive messages from Service Bus Queues via HTTP. If all equipment is connected 12 hours per day, you’re required to pay the following connection fees (excluding any other Service Bus fees): 10,000 HTTP receiving connections * 12 hours/day * 31 days/744 hours = 5,000 transfer connections.
  • Does the transfer connection fee apply to queues and topics/subscriptions?

    Yes. Sending events by HTTP doesn’t require paying connection fees no matter how many sending systems/devices you use. Receiving events by HTTP with a timeout bigger than zero (sometimes called Long-Poll) will generate transfer connection fees. No matter whether the connection is used for sending or receiving, the AMQP connection will generate transfer connection fees. Please note, in the basic namespace, you can use at most 100 free transfer connections, which are the maximum transfer connections permitted by every Azure subscription. In every Azure subscription, the first 1,000 transfer connections within any/all standard namespaces are free of charge (not included in basic fees). As these limits are enough to cover many service-to-service plans, there will generally be considerable transfer connection fees only when you plan to use AMQP or HTTP Long-Poll on numerous clients, namely, to realize more efficient events flow or activate two-way communication of thousands/millions of devices or application instances.

  • If my Azure subscription has multiple standard namespaces, am I charged the basic fees multiple times?

    No. Every Azure subscription is only required to pay the monthly basic fees of a standard edition message transfer. This means that after you create a standard level Service Bus namespace, you will be able to create any number of standard level namespaces in the same Azure subscription without generating any additional basic fees.

    For other common questions about Service Bus billing, please refer to MSDN articles.

  • What is a mixed connection?

    Mixed connection can help establish two-way binary stream communication between two networked applications, one or two of which can remain behind NAT or a firewall. You can implement listener receiving “Relay” connections and transmitter sending “Relay” connections, provided that you adopt any language supporting basic WebSocket functions (including the WebSocket API of most Web browsers).

  • How are mixed connections billed?

    When creating the first mixed connection listener, expenses are paid according to the rate of every listener unit. Every individual listener created is charged at the same rate. The services include 5GB of free data transmission every month. You can use this 5GB free data transmission in all listener units. If the total data transmissions among all listener units exceed 5GB, the extra data transmission is charged.

    Pricing example 1: If a listener has been installed (e.g.: a mixed connection manager instance) and has run continuously one month, and also sent 3GB of data across the connection, the total expenses are RMB 76.09.

    Pricing example 2: If a listener has been installed (e.g.: a mixed connection manager instance) and has run continuously one month, and has also sent 10GB of data across the connection, the total expenses are RMB 143.077: RMB 76.087 (connection and the first 5GB) + RMB 66.99 (extra 5GB data).

    Pricing example 3: If the two mixed connection manager instances (A and B) have been installed and have run continuously one month, and have also sent 3GB of data across connection A and 6GB of data across connection B, the total expenses are RMB 205.766: RMB 76.087 (connection A) + RMB 76.087 (connection B) + RMB 53.592 (4GB extra data due to connection A 3GB + connection B 6GB).

  • Is there a data transmission fee for connection to the mixed connection listener?

    Every connection to a listener is charged with a fee of 64KB. The aforementioned data size will be deducted from the 5GB provided free of charge to the listener unit every month. The listener unit fee is calculated every hour by taking 5 minutes as the increment. Multiple openings and closings for the purpose of development/testing are not charged.

  • How long does the mixed connection listener stay open if there is no data transmission? What is the fee for keeping connection open?

    If the connection is opened but hasn’t transmitted any data, we will transmit 1KB every minute to keep the connection available on your behalf. Doing this prevents the network from disconnecting automatically every few minutes.

Support and Service Level Agreements

If you have any questions or need help, please visit Azure Support and select self-help service or any other method to contact us for support.

For Service Bus Relay, we guarantee that at least 99.9% of the time, applications configured correctly can establish connections with the deployed relay.

For the Service Bus queues and themes, we guarantee that at least 99.9% of the time, applications configured correctly can send or receive messages or perform other operations on the deployed queues or topics.

To learn more about the details of our service level agreement, please visit the Service Level Agreements page.
